The reason why I give this four stars and not 5 is because my Ramen came with one piece of pork. To add another would have been $3 and the pork is not that good. They also didn't let me sub pork belly for the roasted pork which sucked because I love Ramen places that are very accommodating to your taste. The egg also lacked flavor and was not runny at all which is a major bummer. Overall, for being $10 for the ultra spicy and $8 for the Tonkotsu, it's not a bad place to go, and considering the broth is the best I've had in Arizona, I will be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Tonkotsu
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Pork bun
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Tonkotsu- $8 an awesome. Get the rich broth!

HoI0gDo4Jo8HSPAVRpu1Vw.text: A friend and I had a lunch date and it was packed on a Saturday...  PROS -Octopus bowl appetizer - tried something new and had a strange but cool texture, it was fried on the outside but a little softer in the middle. There were shavings of something one top that freaked me out a little, but still taste. 6 of them to share in the app. -eggs in both dishes were cooked really well -we were please w/the slice of pork in our ramen - a lot more flavor and carmelized than other places in AZ  CONS -Service was slow, we asked for plates multiple times for our app -Broth - for both the spicy miso and Tonkatsu...there was no flavor...my friend said his was not spicy at all it just looked spicy...i had to add all these different flavorings from the table and was still not satisfied with it fully  It was just an average ramen place. Is it better than Republic Ramen in Tempe? Yes, but I have yet to find an above average ramen place in the East Valley.

xGT8Z8Tr07d9x_xigdz7aw.text: Not a fan. I know I didn't get what I wanted but no one who worked there could help. My girlfriend liked it.  I didn't even eat what I ordered and that is crazy, I like food.

UD4YWaTrWdZwFeLyZ8D5GQ.text: I really like Tampopo Ramen, especially the spicy miso. I always go back there because it's good and service is nice. Also, they have nice appetizers.

Zy6EgMFbv4OCH0DgmuLT_Q.text: Coming from cali, there are numerous ramen joints where staff greets you enthusiastically  in unison. Where you know despite the language barrier you're getting something worth the 30 min plus wait...THIS was not one of those places. The prices were decent, cheaper than even some of the pho spots we've been to in az, which was a first for us but even then we were in agreement this would probably be our last visit here.   The ramen looked like ramen, it smelled like ramen but there were so many things missing. We had such high hopes, but the broth was incredibly sweet, sweeter than any ramen I've ever had. And didn't have for a lack of a better word, the creaminess that tonkotsu broth often has. Another one off the list for our search for good ramen in az...

bUW7wU1xqNmRuLVkCiSCXA.text: Went here today, mind you it's 110 outside... They must be trying to conserve $ at the consumers comfort expense.. I thought it might be just me.. But Everyone I looked at was sweating like me miserable in there so I walked and looked at the thermostat.. It was set @93 on a 110 degree day.. Wtf... Never coming back in the summer I can tell you that.. If anyone happens to go here.. Plan on being a sweat box and leave in puddles of wetness and be thankful when you get on your car with ac!

DXVj_GhWm38AK59a3oDG7w.text: First time here. I was not disappointed the food was delicious and customer service was great too. But if you are wondering why the four stars... the place had their music playing a little too loud. But overall I will definitely be coming here again!

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

1iY0m7bCC2v0X-WUNugn5w.text: My daughter is an ASU student and we go here for dinner when I am in town both she and her room mate love it.  I do as well. They often split the miso soup and a pork bun with green tea.

ExAFD5dXVa8ur1NdESWJSg.text: Let me start by saying I am not your typical ramen lover. I grew up eating instant ramen and when I realized there were restaurants serving authentic ramen, I decided to give it a try. Out of all the places I've been to, Tampopo Ramen is the best one I've had in AZ! They made me become a ramen lover. The first time I came I got the seafood ramen and absolutely loved it. Today I tried the ultra spicy ramen and it was good as well but I do prefer the seafood ramen more because of its broth. If you are one who can handle your spice, you'll agree with me that the ultra spicy ramen does have a kick to it but it's not "ultra spicy". I feel like I got more spice from adding in their spice paste called "Bakudan" to my seafood ramen when I first visited. Also, it was hard for me to enjoy the ultra ramen broth because it was more dense, which is something I do not prefer. Nonetheless, the ramen was still tasty and I still think this is one of the best places to get ramen. I love how their ingredients are freshly made and how their seating environment resembles an authentic Japan experience!  PS- Do not wear a white shirt while eating the ultra spicy ramen, especially if you're a messy eater like me!

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Ultra spicy ramen with added shrimp and corn!

Aconvuvx6P0gB70klpDsEw.text: Pretty cool. Just like Japanese ramen restaurant- pretty cool. Food is excellent. Asahi draft beer w nice Japanese chicken and octopus balls for appetizer and incredible noodles  nice happy atmosphere and truly amazing experience. We will definitely go back

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

pK1U9fnopOAtC9C4KQPZaA.text: I might be in the minority, but the ramen here just isn't really up my alley. Because the seating is very limited, the restaurant is always crowded. After trying the tonkotsu ramen, I think that the noodles are too thin (reminiscent of angel hair pasta) and chasu has too much of a smoky flavor. However, the broth is decent. At the price point of around $11, I would definitely choose Nishikawa Ramen (Chandler) or even Ramen Dozo (Tempe) over this place.

TVfcW6w2oLSjMUz8Rrf3rQ.text: Overcooked egg, flavorless pork, broth was underwhelming, service can be best described as "passive aggressive". At least the mediocre ramen was warm?  If you're in the area, do yourself a favor and go across the street to Dozo. The difference is night and day.

dsS7yCs1iNPqswMnZxpVJQ.text: Is this place a fad or what?  Went here a few weeks ago with an Ethnic Lunch Meetup group.  The menu is simple and short on variety, but it IS a ramen restaurant so that's what you get:  ramen in all sorts of different broths to choose from with different proteins.  I got the spicy ramen with two slices of pork and a hard boiled egg.  It was definitely spicy in a reddish thick broth.  It was OK.  One guy got the Curry Ramen and didn't like it--said it had no flavor.  One lady ordered the octopus balls as an appetizer.  While the presentation was pretty, they were a gooey mess inside.  I was not a fan.  If you order a soft drink or iced tea, they will bring it in a can with a glass of ice.  They do have beer and sake.  I don't need to go back here.  I think they have a lot of fans, so that's good.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. The Extra Spicy Ramen

54hHRTAl_E9_8ssgRu5wRw.text: I ordered the tonkutsu ramen. The portion is fine but the taste is weird, different than any tonkutsu ramen I have ever tried. When we were waiting for the table, another group of 4 people came. They were welcomed to the 4 person table at the end of the store while no one came to clean the 2 person table supposedly for us. They had service before us even we came first and waited much longer than them. I don't know how they can have such nice reviews, but I definitely won't come again.

xWU143cMOV3PkZhjdd9U5w.text: Yes!!!! I've eaten here several times and it never gets old.  I can see why Naruto loves ramen so much!!!!!Everything is tasty. I can see why this spot is so popular. Choose your time wisely when stopping by. It gets full and busy here. We've been lucky enough to visit during not so busy times. Yasss ramen!!!! Yassss!!!!

IEyeG5FTkGcl9iLFFuIlvA.text: This ramen is whack... why y'all fooling the yelpers out here giving this place 4 stars? Either some of you have never had good ramen or you were just surprised this ain't Maruchan. Service was great and the workers were friendly but I will not be going back because the ramen was very alright.

l0KTKyRTnl6OdGr96F7CZQ.text: I want to write a quick disclaimer saying that at time of writing I've got a stuffed nose so that might've effected me a little bit.  Anyhow, went here with my foodie partner in crime after hearing other ramen fans rave about this place. Needless to say my expectations were very high.   I grabbed the Tonkatsu ramen and added fried chicken and white onion to it while my buddy got the miso ramen.  This Tonkatsu is probably the mildest I've had so far. I feel there was a certain hardiness missing from it. That being said, this wasn't a terrible thing. There's been ramen in the past that was too dang salty and I had to guzzle water just to eat it.  My hang up comes up after getting to try a spoonful of the miso broth and realizing how much more flavor that bowl had. Either this cold is throwing me off, or I chose poorly.   Moving on from broth we had a lovely slice of roasted pork belly, black fungus, bean sprouts, scallions, and the egg in addition to the added fried chicken and white onions. The pork belly was my favorite part and I wished you got more than 1 slice. It was tasty. Same goes with the added fried chicken. The 3 pieces were satisfying and flavorful. The other toppings in this bowl seemed very well-rounded. Heck I usually pass on anything fungus but these black fungus strips were good. The egg wasn't my favorite thing, but then again, I don't eat hard or soft boiled eggs. Food buddy enjoyed her egg so if you enjoy soft boiled eggs you'll probably enjoy the ones here as well.   Honorable mention goes to the noodles here! Their consistency and texture are way different than the squiggly noodles found at other places. They really seem fresh and not like they've been sitting in a plastic bag for a while.   Serving sizes here are just about perfect. The bowl you get is so cute and the toppings aren't drowning in the broth. Ratio of broth to stuff just seems correct.   Overall rating and impression: satisfied but not excited. Definitely going to return in the future when I'm 100% healthy and give it another go.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Tonkatsu ramen with white onion and fried chicken

_5VbGCYEKS162udiznB62w.text: I had the teriyaki over rice bowl while the rest of my friends got ramen. Just a heads up--almost all the ramen has broth that is pork based with the exception of the seafood ramen.   The presentation of all the dishes are really nice, but I was not a fan of my teriyaki chicken over rice at all. It was a nice portion size for 5$, but not all that appetizing.   As for the service, the staff is nice but since the place is so busy, that they never answer the phone. My friend thought he may have left his credit card there after we left the restaurant. So we called and got put on hold forever and then got hung up on ughh. I imagine it'd be hard to do takeout because they don't tend to answer their phones. The place itself is really casual--very loud and very hot. It felt as if there was no AC running. I probably wouldn't be back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Teriyaki Over Rice

vh7Ow_ILtNHptq2nmPQKow.text: Recommended: yeah good flavor and fast service Food: Food overall it's good.  Service: Service is average. The food comes out pretty quick.  Cons: the restaurant is pretty small. You maybe sitting next to other people like if you were in a bar but a bit more cramped all around.   Details: This place has some good ramen. I normally order Tonkotsu at Japanese ramen places. Although the ramen are decently pretty good but it's not my personal favorite. This place has the white ramen noodles but I normally prefer the yellow noodles for my Tonkotsu ramen. They serve their ramen with very little amount of broth but flavorful still. Since their broth is very concentrated for the flavor, they only put barely enough of broth to cover the ramen noodles. And then place the other ingredients on top so you could see the presentation of them. They also service their Tonkotsu ramen with a hard boil egg. I believe this is close to the traditional way but I had place where their egg is poached instead which it is creamier texture added to the ramen. Of course it depended on personal preference.    Cons: I normally don't come here often since this restaurant is pretty small. They have about three rows. One row has table tops, one middle section row that you would most likely sit next to a random person while sitting across from ur friend/family. It's a very condense place and it's only enough for one person to walk between the rows. And last row is similar to sitting at a bar where ur facing the kitchen and cooks. I think because of this reason, a lot of people don't come often or order to go.

UMm8jY0QwAOPppPUNmr2Yg.text: Very flavorful ramen soup Attentive staff Can get very crowded due to the size of the place Overall had a very pleasant experience

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Tonkotsu ramen
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Yummy Takoyaki!

jhrIzYGkLNvHVdpPrc02Qw.text: I had pretty much given up hope of finding a decent ramen place in the United States, but Tampopo Ramen appeared to save the day!  The pork belly appetizer tastes amazing. Really fatty and melts in your mouth. Ugh, SOOO GOOD.  The cucumber and sesame oil dish is okay.. I probably should have added more salt or something. It was a little too oily but bland.  The spicy ramen tasted amazing! It would have been nice to be able to customize the softness of the noodles, but hey, we are in not in Japan so whatever.  Note that the tonkatsu ramen uses peanut oil. My sister is allergic to nuts, so it's a good thing that the ingredients are listed!  The service is great!! I had the creamy melon soda thing, which I didn't really love, but it was interesting to try. It was like a fruity cream soda basically.  I would definitely return. It's pretty good and more authentic than most ramen places in the US that I have tried.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

tYr096wpXu4ie4Ny-5S8Ug.text: Came here with a group of 4 the other night and was a little worried we wouldn't get seated right away, not realizing how small this place was and how it is countertop/ bar style seating. However, there was a perfect table in the back for 4 and we're seated immediately!   The service was spot on! Staff was friendly and quick with our orders, drinks, and food! We ordered the pork belly bun to start, along with the agedashi tofu, and the squid balls! The pork bun could have used some more ingredients, I love when restaurants put something pickled or some type of veggie in their bun. It would be nice if they added more bun options as well, was a little disappointed their was only one option. The agedashi tofu however was outstanding! Perfectly crisped on the outside, soft and flavorful on the inside. Mouth is watering right now just writing about it!   Now let's talk ramen. Love that they make their own noodles in house. That was the main reason we came here! They definitely give you a plentiful amount of noodles! You have the option to have original or spicy noodles which you don't see at too many other ramen houses. We all had the spicy ramen, half our table with spicy noodles, other half with original. The pork belly was delicious, I also added fried chicken, bamboo shoots, and seaweed into mine. My egg was cooked perfectly, soft boiled with more of a wet yolk, however my girlfriends yolk was overdone. Do wish there was a little more broth, the noodles seemed to take over the bowl.   Overall 4/5 stars I would definitely come back to get a ramen fix in! Would like to try their tonkotsu next time :)

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

EXlJ7pLI5wtz3Garmu8Jtw.text: The ramen here was decent and the service was fine. They were busy but we got in no problem.  I was really excited for the pork buns but there was waaaay too much sauce that overpowered everything and I could barely taste the pork. Sad about that :(

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Pork bun
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Spicy Miso Ramen

G4e0qmYE15AfthXe9FV2Aw.text: This Mom & Pop shop offers some of the most authentic ramen you can get in the valley.  I always opt for getting the strong broth as it is an umami bomb of flavor.  The only downside is that they have tried to jam as many seats in this tiny space as possible, resulting of you feeling claustrophobic when they are busy.  Hopefully, they will become successful enough to move to a more spacious location.

UJ3xQDL8zY_2uGggh88OJQ.text: I cannot say enough good things about this place. Being Japanese I have grown up around several authentic and yummy ramen places around me in Hawaii and was so bummed I was not going to find a place with the same experience when I made my move to the desert. To my surprise, I found this gem right by my house and have fit this restaurant into my restaurant routine.   Every visit I have had here I have not been disappointed in the service. Being that this restaurant has a smaller/more intimate setting the service compliments it perfectly. My favorite spot to eat at is at the ramen bar being that you can actually see the chefs create your dish for you using their signature broths and handmade noodles.   My favorite dish that I have tried is the Miso Ramen. Every dish is customizable and you are able to add/subtract any of the toppings that they carry which can be great for vegetarians or dietary restrictions. I have also tried the Ultra Spicy Ramen which I definitely recommend if you want to add a kick to your day!  Overall, I cannot say enough great things about this place and really is a little taste of home every time I visit. I hope you enjoy it too!

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Love their Miso Ramen here!

sgUvICjDoojIZHd3o56zew.text: I love all types of ramen. That said, I have to give praise where praise is due. Tampopo's handmade noodles are on point. My family and I came here with a friend from out of town. We were seated quickly and given our menus (pro tip: come early, it is small and fills fast). My eyes were INSTANTLY drawn to the Ultra Spicy Ramen as I am a sucker for scorching foods. My wife, daughter and friend went with the more normal tonkotsu and seafood ramen respectively.   The food came quickly and my wife's soup was amazing. It had rich pork flavor and plenty of noodles. It was, however, a little light on actual pork. My friend loved his seafood ramen as well (I couldn't try as I am very allergic to shellfish). Even my 2 year old daughter devoured her portion of my wife's bowl.  My ramen, however, was a disappointment. Yes, it was spicy (not as much as they proclaim in my opinion) and yes it has the fixings. My issue was the flavor and texture of the broth. It had almost no flavor, just burn. I've eaten numerous items which are delicious but also a ring burner. This wasn't like that at all. The texture of the broth isn't like a nice soup like the other broths nor is it thick but delectable like a stew (or even hot and sour soup from a Chinese restaurant). Oh no, it had the texture of mud. This thick, brown and red, mud. It was very, very unappetizing. It didn't work with the comically large spoon you are given nor the chopsticks (the broth makes it nearly impossible to grasp the noodles). I was able to make my way through the noodles but will not be having it again.   Tampopo gets 4 stars as everyone else's food was amazing and I'll come back for a normal bowl of ramen soon. But man, I can't recommend the ultra spicy ramen to anyone. Blech.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

1lJzTUaZfoOiMaarfzIC9g.text: If I could eat here every day, I swear I would. I love Tampopo Ramen and believe it's the best ramen shop we've got here in Phoenix! I love bringing friends and family here so they can taste the goodness that is Tampopo's handmade noodles and savory broths. And that melt-in-your-mouth buttery pork?! Deeelish.   My go to order is the Miso Ramen, add mushrooms and add extra pork. I truly believe extra pork is the key here... I cannot get enough! I really love their hard-boiled eggs, which tend to be more on the soft-boiled side. That runny deep yellow egg yolk is so good! My boyfriend likes spicy food so he usually orders the Ultra Spicy Ramen, and adds extra pork per my suggestion of course. He loves the level of spice, but has admitted that it can be overpowering and can take away from the actual flavor of the ramen. For those who like spicy but don't LOVE it, he suggests the regular spicy ramen, not ultra spicy.   Tampopo Ramen is a small restaurant with some communal seating, but I've never waited longer than 10 minutes for a spot to slurp down some noodles. You can sit at the bar and watch the chefs hard at work, but be warned that it's a lot warmer up near the kitchen. I made the mistake of sitting there in July and I couldn't stop sweating. But, I also couldn't stop myself from eating a huge bowl of steaming ramen even though it was 115* outside.

D2zFX5H6lIzJptDnkwk8-A.text: Such a tiny little place that packs the flavor. They offer different vegetarian options and they are have a ton of options for the meat eaters. I cannot wait to go again! Service is quick and friendly. I'm not sure why this place isn't more widely know.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. My canned green tea
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Vegetarian ramen

wSRwSeFdUqVybvOI7WS8hg.text: I showed up as they reopened for dinner (5:00 PM) and by 5:30 they were hopping! Even though the place was full they were very attentive and friendly. I loved that all the wait staff took care of anyone needing something, unlike normal models where you need to track down your assigned waiter/waitress to get help, great model for this atmosphere.   I ordered the spicy miso ramen and it had so much flavor going on I didn't need to add anything additional, I just devoured it. I did order additional noodles as I got down to broth in the bottom of my bowl and unfortunately they were a bit under cooked, not a big deal just a byproduct of how busy they were.   Definitely worth the visit if your looking for some ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

PgE4-AcrATCU6bz_TbncKA.text: I have eaten here two times in the last week! Definitely a solid ramen place in the valley. I got the tonkotsu ramen. I've also tried the goyza. Everything is pretty solid. The noodles are fresh and cooked well. You can actually see them make The noodles fr3sh when you walk in on the right. The cha shu is one of the best I've had in a ramen. They make sure to char it, which gives a greater level of flavor. The second time I went, they were heavy with the pepper but overall, a solid ramen place for a reasonable price. They also give you a good amount of food for the price. The broth is not too salty but is flavorful. The place is small and narrow but it gives a nice communal vibe, which I don't mind. Definitely a place I will frequent in the future.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

XttqmbnCG9HvSpB2omZRBg.text: I would skip the Hirata Buns. The steamed buns ($3 each) were dry and hard. The yaki gyoja $6.50 filled rice things were interesting but I felt the flavor of the filling was too burnt-like for me.  This is the first time I've tried soymilk ramen and it was like you'd imagine. A soymilk soup. Interesting, but I'd probably stick to the tonkotsu next time. I ordered an egg for $2 extra because I like the egg in ramen more than the pork sometimes.  Both the tonkotsu and spicy mison ramen broths and noodles were tasty. I wish all the bowls were "rich soup" instead of having to pay an extra dollar. But maybe that's alright since some people don't care about the boniness/fattiness of their broth and it would be wasted.  At the starting price for $8.00 without any add-ons for a bowl of ramen, I feel the price is reasonable and would encourage repeat customers. Cute place and fun atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Tonkotsu $8+$1 rich soup
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. soymilk ramen $9+$1 rich soup+$2 nitamago (egg)
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. hirata bun $3

l0SljJnndY_QHkpzmpCHrg.text: This hole in the wall place is so crowded inside, It literally felt like I was packed like sardines. The chairs are so close together, we had to keep our elbows in as we slurped on our noodles.   The noodles are made in house and was absolutely delicious. The consistency and texture was spot on. The broth wasn't overly salted which was big relief.   We tried three different ramens. The tonkatsu was my favorite in terms of broth and toppings. The soft boiled egg was seasoned well and was very satisfying. Consider ordering extra for added protein.   The spicy miso had korean gochujang flavor mixed in with miso. It was funky for me but my son seemed to enjoy it. The ultra spicy ramen comes with spicy broth as well as spice infused noodles making this dish extra spicy. However, the broth (I should say 'sauce' because it was really thick) had again gochujang and tobasco flavor which was really strange combo and didn't taste right. Hubby didn't care for this dish either. Again, tonkatsu ramen was very good.   The takoyaki was delicious but it was on super soft/mushy side. It was seasoned well too.   Overall, the cramped seatings took away from the experience. I would go back for the food.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Ultra spicy ramen
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Spicy miso ramen
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Tonkatsu ramen

faf1WsAm_M60Qom8nt-RHg.text: Tampopo Ramen is THE bomb. Best tasting ramen I've had in the valley. Every time I visit, my tastebuds AND wallet leave happy.  The prices at Tampopo are fantastic. $11 Ramen, $6 rice bowls, and a full stomach?? Heck yeah. My fiance and I usually share a ramen bowl and a rice bowl and still can't finish everything.   The miso ramen is so tasty and I can never get enough of the broth. I always order the same thing and never get tired of it.  The fried chicken here is also perfectly cooked and crispy and pairs really well with the rice and sesame seaweed on top. I usually get the braised pork rice bowl which is also very amazing. The braised pork is so tender and just melts in your mouth. Yum   Whenever you're craving comfort food, Tampopo is the place to go. It gets pretty busy at times which means seating can get pretty cozy since there's only bar seating, a long communal table and maybe 5 small side tables that can only fit 2 people.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

QsssjJkNakYiw1t2esaVUQ.text: This is a really solid Ramen spot. I've been coming here about once every two or three weeks for the last few months. The noodles here are really good and fresh. The customer service is great although sometimes there's a bit of a wait. But overall I've been really happy and will continue to come back because they do a good job.

kVF6t6e4PAlWvuoibXAjiA.text: Love taking my friends here! Not gonna lie, was not excited about going somewhere to get ramen. But tampopo is amazing and I refuse to eat anything besides tampopo. They have great appetizers too! I get the miso ramen it is amazing. You can get a vegetarian version as well. It is a small place and you can't make reservations. Around 740 on the weekend you can't even walk inside. It is well worth the wait and people definitely do!

bBZbGdADL8FWU-2E3JF-ww.text: Went for the first time having extremely high expectations. I ordered fried chicken on rice, which was disappointing. The pieces were small, and there was no seasoning or sauce to save the dry taste. It was just.....plain rice with chicken so it was at the most underwhelming. The miso ramen was just subpar. Maybe we ordered the wrong things...maybe our next visit will be better.

7ufd_kRljSkZmpmwisk_6Q.text: Disappointed... Really wanted ramen but was a let down.  Very take out seating and not much flavor in the soup.  Would not return.

5FWtbH2lAMGvUWnhAZ9oxA.text: One of my favorite restaurants in Tempe.  Consistently delicious. If you haven't been here,  stop reading and go.

U94aRIQ5tqZAr5Cti7aBkw.text: A family run Ramen shop serving handmade noodle with a good complex broth. The kitchen shows Ramen experience that I haven't seen in Phoenix before. They have Asahi Super Dry on tap and a good selection of sake.. it's the real deal and worth a try.

9F81abMCNLt9C3hOYXKIXg.text: Comparable to republic ramen. The broth is better than amy in Arizona I've had. Smaller slices of meat would be nice but I am not complaining. The real reason I love this place is the ambiance and how hot the broth is, cant beat it!

UqRSFKCRRvF5JVY8-4BqHw.text: This place is something of a hidden gem. The menu is simple and direct. The sake and beer selection pairs well with the flavors the menu offers.This is by no means a date place. This is casual, relaxed dining. The place is on the small side. Prepare to get cozy if you are staying.  Each bowl is filling, but if you need more, $2 refills the bowl.  I love that this place understands that spicy/hot should not come at the expense of flavor. I lieder the ultra spicy all the time, but it is not just hear. There is an actual increase in bold, standout flavor as well. Adding pork and wild mushrooms or shrimp is always nice,  and these additions are not skimped on.   For lunch or happy hour,  this place is fun and relaxed. For happy hour there are some nice deals on some interesting appetizers. Once again, even these are Ali about nice, robust flavor. It's hard to go wrong ordering anything here.

PXU2d6mc7EWjYz6NmfXXhA.text: Food: 8/10 Service: 9/10 Value: 7/10  Decent ramen with good favor broth. They got an actual ramen maker out by the entrance, which is kind of cool. Got the spicy miso ramen, gyoza, and takoyaki. Mediocre compared to Tokyo, NYC, SF, LA, or Hawaii. But if you want to get your ramen fix in Phoenix, this is the spot to go.

_v4WkMYrLgn74PgnXvNsEQ.text: So disappointed. Broth was disgusting..full of scum over boiled and never strained... awful awful... should be much cleaner... literally got the bottom crap... soo much black pepper.... and scum it wasn't edible... the pork was good but fatty... this is unfortunately bad... umami is hands down 10000% better... hit me up I know real ramen in the valley if you don't want to waste your money. All this food in the trash... and my take out is wrong.... paid extra for pork got that but didn't get the pork that comes with the actual dish... I expect some answers... I will actually waste my gas to come back in and show you how to make a proper stock and I want my money back..

j472TBmoRpmYd9rV5c1bXg.text: Very disappointed with what I got today. Ordered a Miso Ramen with a double order of pork and no scallions. Received a single tiny piece of pork and a hunk of scallions. Got charged for a double order of Pork despite getting nothing that even resembled my value. Step it up Tampopo I expect better from you.

ngDaXvsMGwLlV9Rea16mxw.text: This place was the best... our server was great, I would definitely go back and recommend this place... love the spicy miso ramen!!!!

EzHQA3osA4Ar8xFiG8PiRg.text: As a japanese. I eat ramen almost everyday in japan. Their ramen is not that good for me. I love the noodles but i dont like the soup they made. I ordered tokotsu ramen. Its my opinion. Try and find out.

ln761GOGzNN0lu-ZZPyFmg.text: I have mixed feelings about this place. I came here with a friend from out of town who happens to be a vegetarian. We sat at the bar and enjoyed fairly good service (our food did sit in the window for a bit, and I was tempted to just go grab it, but I refrained). I was excited to try this place, as my go to ramen establishment just closed to relocate (umami) and I am currently ramenless. I ordered the super extra spicy ramen and my friend had the only vegetarian option which was a soy milk based ramen. The workers were nice enough to put his pork on the side so I could eat it. Anyway, the ramen came out and was a bit small for the price (9-10$). Each dish only came with one piece of pork that was mostly fat. The parts of the pork that were not fat did taste good. The ramen was served with giant odd wooden spoons that were difficult to eat with due to the cup portion being mostly flat. The flavor of my ramen was good, spicy, but not too spicy. The noodles also were tasty, and I appreciate that they are made in house. The best part of the ramen was the egg.... it was just slightly soft in the middle and added a lot of flavor to the soup. My friend's vegetarian ramen was not so good. It tasted a bit like alfredo sauce and really nothing like ramen. It had some peppers in it that were still very crunchy and didn't taste like they had been in the soup at all. This was pretty disappointing. Anyway, I would suggest that this restaurant look into making a soy based broth that mimics traditional ramen as an option for vegetarians. Additionally, I feel that their prices should be lower OR they should fill the bowl and maybe give (gasp) two slices of pork.... it just wasn't enough to justify the price. I may give this establishment another shot and hopefully it will get better as time goes on.

LmBrYb3O0w1uQBt8UobLGw.text: I have to be honest here, I cant even lie about it even if I tried. The food is awful. My sister and I came in and ordered three appetizers: agadashi tofu, japanese chicken wings, and gyoza. We asked our waitress if the gyoza is hand made or store bought and she had the audacity to lie in front of my face saying its hand made. I tried it and it is the most common purchased gyoza at your local lee lee oriental super market. My god.. Each of the appetizers were 7$ and the portion is ridiculous as well as the taste. The chicken wing tasted like its been put into the fryer and someone dripped some soy sauce on it. The tofu is not a normal agadashi tofu size and it taste bland and under fried. The worst part was the ramen... I got the signature tonkatsu ramen and double meat. Thats my biggest mistake of the night. I always taste the broth first as it is the indicator to how good the ramen will be. And it taste like aged water... The noodle was alright and the pork tasted like burnt shit. I would highly not recommend this place. The only time i can see someone giving this place more than a 2 star is when that person had poverty standards. Oh.. Im giving this place a 1 star because even the service was terrible. Never a refill or taken any of the appetizer plates away. Good luck

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. To die or not to die... I came here and died..

RxAMs7VyZYr-ZLQ_iR15_w.text: Second favorite ramen place (diehard Umami fan). They have really awesome broth, meat, and ramen noodles. Ask them to add butter to your broth. I swear, it'll be best thing you ever do. They'll look at you weird, but it is so worth it. I usually get the Tonkotsu, but you can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The portion sizes are pretty large too. I always end up taking half to go.

Tyg7KYjrr-1-smI8ZKaZ3A.text: I had the Ultra Spicy Ramen with the spicy noodles. I love spicy. This is not spicy for me but it is still really good. It made my nose run which is good but not enough for me to say it's spicy. That probably doesn't make any sense but if you have a high spicy tolerance, you'll understand. The meat is very good, I added an extra portion of pork belly. I think they could cut back just a little bit on the large onion slices and bean sprouts but overall, noms.

mPb23uYRidhDXBBbK_CTww.text: Small restaurant. Good ramen. Just try it.

3s6E4Q5gggjbLmgo9n-ZaQ.text: With recommendation from foodie friends, I have come to this place to check out their famous Ramen.  The presentation was decent and I saw the master chef put his huge bone marrow into the broth to my delight.  The problems came with mostly services.  She has very little idea when to clear the table and kept on asking me am I done (twice) which I feel like she wants to confiscate my soup.  The right way to ask is If I am still working on it instead.  The soup was underseasoned broth so I had to enhance with Japanese chili oil, spices, and caviar.  The agedashi tofu broth is improper (light soy sauce expected instead of eel soy sauce)..Tacoyaki is great but with too much dry fish which covered the flavors of octopus balls.  I will have to go back for others and evaluate others and see if I will return.  My status with this place is still pending..

zhAo3jRaZjuJry7H2eLHGQ.text: This was excellent! I had the ultra spicy ramen with the soy milk base and it was superb. I'm glad that I found a Ramen place that has a vegetarian option, as it's next to impossible.   I will definitely be back for the soy milk broth

ATIiFVPtCFnfCLSDLmD9fA.text: Service was fast and accommodating. Location is a bit small and cramped, so bringing a large party may be difficult. Should call before to check how busy it is beforehand. Other than that, great service and great food. Ordered the tonkotsu ramen and really enjoyed it. Would come again and would recommend.

ax34naHGpjZqJQyFt7nTlA.text: Outstanding fresh-made ramen. Reminds me of a small Japanese ramen house in Fussa. It has the obvious American-isms, but all for the better. Great wait staff. It could benefit from a lower a/c setting.

cETSZDr9ImhRnSWAFGpzOA.text: I've seen posts from friends on FB about Tampopo.  So I dined here not once, but twice in a week.  The restaurant is small.  But even though this place lacks space, they know how to prepare yummy ramen!  Most Ramen-ya in Japan is crowded without chairs because people are on the go.  Tampopo tries to keep the traditional ramen-ya without the Western frills.  So don't even think about hanging out with friends to talk and catch up at the dinner table, please go elsewhere.    My first bowl was the tonkatsu ramen.  The broth was rich with a lot of depth.  The noodles was just the right texture and chew.  Customers are able to see that the noodles are fresh as you walk in.  To complement my meal we had takoyaki and wasabi tako.  They were both really, really delicious.    My next bowl was the ultra spicy ramen.  The hot factor was just as good as my love for Korean spicy food.  It was a cold evening, so my ramen was the perfect cure.  This place won over my husband's appetite.  He got extra pork and egg for his ramen.  The kids for once didn't complain and they enjoyed the takoyaki with the generous amount of bonito flakes.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. My ultra spicy ramen...it was oishii !!!

krIqDgNqbp5xIlYelQf9XQ.text: Reasonably priced, tasty ramen. This restaurant used to be a sushi place but has now been converted to serve delectable freshly pulled noodles.   I ordered the tampopo ramen ($8) with the rich broth upgrade ($1 extra). It was served in a short amount of time, and a hearty portion of veggies, a nicely cooked whole egg, noodles, and meat. The broth was indeed rich and flavorful and the noodles were very fresh with a chewy texture. The pork was well seasoned and went well with the ramen.  Service was good and I was checked up on as needed. Note that there is no soda fountain so soda is by the can or bottle (Coke products and Ramune).  The space itself is quite small so it can feel a bit cramped. There are only a few side tables that sit 2, a very long table in the center, and bar seating.  I'll definitely come here again to try more dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Soymilk ramen no bean sprouts
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Spicy miso ramen, no bean sprouts
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Bring on the heat! Ultra spicy ramen, no bean sprouts

OubCFtjhy2ZGMe3SzDePtg.text: New ramen restaurant in Phoenix! I saw one of yelper's checkin a few days ago and couldn't wait to try here for myself.  Grand opening was Monday 11/2, so still new here. Looking at menu, I thought they really researched Phoenix market by adding several spicy options  I was in search of authentic Hakata ramen, so I stayed with basic Hakata ramen with my noodle al-dente, just like True Hakata style.  Ramen came with kikurage (can't remember English name) but dark seaweed looking one on the picture I posted. Very authentic. Soft boiled egg was warm and flavorful.   Unfortunately they put too much black paper on my soup and couldn't really enjoy the broth. I add black pepper only to Sapparo ramen. Hakata ramen goes well with sesame.   I also ordered side of gyoza. Gyoza tasted very authentic, and I enjoyed them well.  Service was not there yet. Considering they just opened, I thought it wasn't fair to say anything yet.  Next time when I come back, I will ask them not to add any black pepper in my soup, and pay small extra to add more flavor to my soup. Let's see how that gets close to what I am used to eat every time I visit Fukuoka.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Gyoza appetizer $6.50 for 6 pieces
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Basic Hakata ramen (nothing additional) $8

OrLcXYHoeSxA-fNBeGVpbA.text: First time at Tampopo tonight.  I tried the spicy miso to-go, which was very good.  I wish there had been a bit more meat in it, but the flavor was good and I was very pleased with my choice.  I tried the buns as a side, which had a good taste but I wish again had a little more meat.    I am giving a five star rating because the service was very good.  The food was probably worthy of a 4-star rating but I was very pleased with the help of the girl at the counter.  The restaurant was PACKED, I was shocked how busy it was on a Thursday night.  The girl who took my order was kind enough to bring my food out to me in my car so that I could stay in the car with my kids.  Very kind of her to do when the restaurant was so busy!  The fresh noodles were great, will be going back!  UPDATE: Went back for a second try with my daughter.  Service again was excellent and the restaurant wasn't as crazy busy at lunchtime.  Had the ultra spicy and added shrimp.  I certainly wouldn't say that it was ultra spicy but it was still delicious.    I know everyone posts about those octopus balls... I didn't really care for them.  Potstickers were very fresh and delicious!  My daughter loved the fried chicken and rice.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Fried chicken and rice
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Ultra spicy ramen with shrimp in the foreground, fried chicken and rice in the background.
Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. A little nervous about the shrimp looking at her.

kh_etnCXMK7xp8mtPsuCgw.text: This place is a must! Best ramen in town. Hirata bun is really good too. Well worth the 30 minute drive.

3cpl0PGHLLqEQSuIVZWBCg.text: After reading the rave reviews, I was super stoked to try this new ramen place. I got the tori karrage, the Japanese fried chicken, as an appetizer. The chicken was overcooked, rendering the outside to be hard, and inside meat to be dry and chewy - I wasn't very impressed. As for the ramen, my boyfriend and I both got the tonkotsu ramen, adding the rich soup for an additional $1. Honestly, the broth was overly salty and not flavorful/rich. It makes me curious to know how the regular broth would have been since we requested the rich soup (aka concentrated and flavored) and it wasn't banging rich. I was also bummed out that the egg was hard boiled instead of the soft boiled egg with runny yolk inside; the egg was overly done for me. I watched the chef blow torch the pork, and was disappointed when the pork turned out to be super chewy. There is an option to add other toppings to the ramen, which we did not try. Overall, the ramen was pretty generic to me. This is comparing the bomb.com ramen in NorCal, such as Ramen Dojo and Orenchi. The service was fantastic though. The waiters were very attentive and efficient at what they were doing. They really tried hard to make a good impression. Excellent service - it's just the ramen was satisfactory, nothing unique. However, a good alternative if you're craving for some ramen in AZ.

5IDp_cxgiDe-rcYC-j41lg.text: Went there the other day with my daughter.  The ultra spicy ramen is delish. The pork buns oh man yummy!! Well worth the visit!!

Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States

j3LA96cFfCPUECXWPFCnKA.text: I have eaten a lot of ramen. This ramen is not bad. I've ordered the Tonkotsu ramen plenty of times here; upgrading the soup base to rich broth is a good option, otherwise the soup is just so-so. The noodles are indeed made in-house and they aren't phenomenal, but it is cool to see that you are eating homemade noodles.  I have ordered the curry rice here once, and it tastes the exact same as the same Japanese curry rice I make at home using store-bought curry packets. I really am focusing on the ramen though, thus rating a 4/5.  Service is standard, friendly staff, etc. . Seating is kinda wonky but I'm here for the food.

8HS3H241troAK7q7wATdLA.text: I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with rich soup, and paid extra for a topping I did not get. For paying extra for rich soup, the broth was bland and was lacking a hearty thickness that I was expecting. I've had better creamier, thicker broths at other ramen places without having to pay extra for "rich" broth. The noodles were disappointing. They were more like soba noodles than ramen noodles, which are for dipping. The noodles didn't soak up the broth well. Also the noodle and broth ratio was not adequate. There was barely any broth. So when I reboiled the noodles in the broth, the noodles kept sticky to the bottom of the pot. I had to continually stir deeply and scrape the pot to avoid the noodles from sticking. The rice bowls tasted good, but it was expensive for the small portions. The rice and meat get stuffed into a small togo container.

JXjYnbihIPunBTVp2Gmsjw.text: It's really hard to find good ramen place here in AZ oppose to in HI they're everywhere. I was excited that they are starting to pop up here and hoping that there will be more options because I do love a good ramen place.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Ultra Spicy Ramen with fried chicken. Oh so yummy and filling!

-3gxJ1ArBrCtmF91NdfQeQ.text: We couldn't even stay for dinner. We went on a Saturday evening at around 6pm and the heat in the place was unbearable for us and our kids, especially our 8 month old. I can't believe the owners would keep the place open with how hot it was - even the servers were trying to fan themselves to try keep cool. Complete disaster. We'll come back in the winter. Fix your damn A/C!!!

xFbDQqQl5wiUc4iFtLOs-Q.text: Everything an independent noodle shop should be!  House-made noodles, regular & spicy.  Creative menu options.  All delicious!  Very clean and super friendly staff, too!

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Lunch rush

DFJSE9p8WKeXiht-r9bKdA.text: The place is small, mainly bar style seating, only abt 3 tables; of which one can sit 4 people, and it fills up quickly.  The food was good, we order a few appetizers.  Unless they change their vendor for chicken wings, I wouldn't order them.  They were over cooked, with very little meat, but they were crispy and seasoned well.  The gyoza were good.  I opted for the Ultra Spicy Ramen and added pork belly and spicy fish roe.  For me it wasn't spicy, but the others that tried it, it was spicy.  The broth is a heavier pork broth, great for when and if it gets cold out here.  But it was good.

v0uswgnQBU7WXfCa9HUxFQ.text: The Ramen was tasty, I had the curry ramen which was mostly noodles which I liked. The atmosphere was very cramped. Wanna go grab some quick good tasting ramen, it is an alright place to go, want to enjoy the evening or atmosphere pick somewhere else.

2uJlItsnbtCPUmpfcyfpQw.text: I love the whole them and food was great. Definitely I would recommend his restaurant to anyone who's seeking a late night meal with friends or alone. The place will take 5 stars review if it was bigger.

Today.. the service and the ramen was actually wonderful! Great improvement on everything! Thanks !

A7G6v1Vd_p4y0qUDKIInzA.text: I ordered the ultra spicy ramen and a 16oz beer. Before my meal even came I was already sweating from the lack of ac (not acceptable in the middle of July in a ramen place). The "16 oz" beer they brought me was 12 oz and the waitress lied to my face about the portion size. The ramen tasted like a clam based sauce, the pork was dry and thin. So for the 4 ozs of beer they saved and $2 they stole, they lost a paying costumer who will happily tell others to avoid this place.  TLDR: Give this place a miss for their dishonesty and lack of quality in all areas of business...

E4mF1Flh3aisWWHsDjJFFA.text: came here on a late night. Busy had plenty of communal seating at the long table.   Fast and friendly service. I had the spicy miso and I test the ultra spicy tonkatsu broth. They have 2 different types of house-made noodles. Decent.  I do prefer the spiciness of the ultraspicy broth. I just like miso more. I did get the additional $1 "spicy paste." It added a little kick, but the paste is not what I was expecting. Feel more like a spicy  "sweet/sour sauce texture."  Only 1 slice of chasu, which as others have mentioned, the menu says "slices."   miso broth does has a creamy flavor and which is also rich. Easily down a bowl.  list of extras to add on is on the expensive side.  They do have the $2 for more noodle option. kae-dama  I wish they had a ultra spicy miso version.   Would come back if I wanted to alternate between my ramen places from time to time.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Ultra spicy and spicy miso

AKxjujGFcAepNK3oLCAmSw.text: After doing an advance booking for an upcoming trip to the Philippines via Japan. My wife decided that she was in the mood for some ramen.  So, I chose a Ramen shop that would best represent the "closeness" of a typical Japanese ramen shop that she would be experiencing when we visit Japan. This place is diminutive compared to the other Ramen shops in town.  It was a plus that this place also serves Hakata-style and Tonkotsu Ramen. It lent to the authenticity of the experience, albeit, thousands of miles away.  The make their noodles fresh at this place. And it shows in both the texture and flavor.  We ordered the Gyoza for starters. Nothing too special here. It was just average. Now my Ramen was amazing. Even with the minimal toppings, it still quite flavorful. Not too spicy, but just right.  However, my wife's Fried Chicken over Rice dish was about as plain as they come. It really could've used more seasoning.   The service was not that sprightly, either. It took time to get the attention of our waitress, who seemed overwhelmed by the crowd who were packed in like sardines in this place.  If you are in the mood for some great Ramen, this is the place. Just don't get the Friend Chicken. And hopefully, you don't have a vast personal space requirement!

Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Fried chicken over rice

VhsFwBKB2pIJwjk5If9Qsw.text: Ramen was really good. 2nd best I've had in PHX broth 5/5 noodles 5/5 Meat 5/5 Egg 4/5 Presentation 5/5 Gyoza 5/5 Service 5/5

cobBAFFeJ9dE3qjFOZ1f-w.text: Swung by on a Saturday at 1pm, and it wasn't too crowded. I ordered the spicy miso ramen with wood ear. Food came pretty quickly, but it was missing wood ear so I assumed they had just forgotten.  The noodles were pretty good, firm and had body. The broth was pretty good at first sip, but I didn't find myself dying to have more of it. The flavor was more salty than rich, but I could definitely taste the miso in there. The other toppings were alright - the pickled ginger added another depth of spice, but nothing else really stood out. Also, I didn't realize it only came with only one slice of pork (because the menu says "slices of roast pork")? Not to be nit-picky because the pork was good, just disappointed there was just one slice and the menu said otherwise.  When I got the check, it had +$1 for extra bean sprouts - I told the waitress I thought they had just forgotten the wood ear mushrooms, so she ended up just taking it off completely. I probably should have said something when they bowl came, but I didn't think much of it since the food was already in front of me (and I didn't want them to take it back because I was hungry!).  I haven't been to other ramen places in the area so I can't compare in that sense, but the ramen itself was pretty okay, floating at the 3 out of 5 stars range.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Spicy miso ramen

CbFE1Oix8gNG02hLlb06Dw.text: This is probably one of the best if not the best ramen in the state. I'm a sucker for hole in the wall mom and pop shops and this fits the bill. Located on the corner of McClintock and Southern, it's easy to find but sometimes parking can be difficult. The store is sandwiched in between a Starbucks and a few other stores so spaces are limited.  In the dozens of times I've come here, I've never seen it empty. If you go at night you might want to plan on a little bit of a wait. For the most part, the people that dine here look to be the young college crowd. It's pretty quiet and everyone is very respectful. Being a smaller restaurant, it has such a cozy feel.   I basically get the same thing every visit- spicy miso ramen add rich. The rich is a condensed broth option that adds so much depth to the soup. I feel as though sometimes when getting spicy dishes, flavor can be sacrificed for heat but this is not the case here. With the broth, you get an incredibly deep, rich and creamy flavor with just a little kick. If you want more spice, they do make spicy noodles which are a really neat red color. The list of extras you can add is pretty extensive. I love that you can watch the chefs prepare all the food while you wait so there is no question that everything is made to order and fresh.   If you come here, you will not leave disappointed! Just the bowl of ramen itself will fill you up.

photos.caption: Photo of Tampopo Ramen - Tempe, AZ, United States. Spicy miso ramen

lJAlqnikw0zDo0f2e2OsMQ.text: Let me start this off by saying it is extremely difficult to find a decent ramen spot in az though it is getting more diverse in the way of food options, this is still a difficult task. With that being said this place is great, the flavor of the broth is delicious especially if your flavor profile can handle a little bit of spicy. The ingredients are fresh for sure the only thing I did not care for and I know I will catch some flack for stating this, but I do not like the full shrimp with the eyes still attached just sayin. Other than that this place will not disappoint and is worth a shot.

NXAPHAVhsLN4A6K7fiB_Xg.text: It was alright.  Ordered the ultra spicy. Not amazing but it gave me my ramen fix. Wasnt spicy to me but I have a pretty high tolerance (i can eat jalapenos raw).  I would not reccomend doing it as take out. They put it in a standard take out box and adding the soup to the box will definitely result in a mess unless you have a large bowl to put it in (I didn't as I was in a hotel).

I3-Kz1HWVxmHnmDMCXdkbg.text: In the mood for soup on a cold day.. try this place .. small indoor seating area .. small tables and a long communal table down the center of the room.. perfect for single diners or small groups..  Huge bowls of broth & noodles .. I went with the Tonkotsu Ramen (standard bowl of ramen with pork broth) with the roe & scallions (yes that's how I ordered it .. ) .. it was rich and filling ..   Spicy miso and appetizers also delicious .. the menu is not super long but the basics and add ons definitely make each experience great.. get the hot oil for heat .. yum  Seating is tight .. the couple that showed up at 12:30 (lunch time) on a Wed with a huge baby stroller and bumped and forced at least 13 people to move so they could get to the table in the back was aggravating to watch .. don't be that guy!

sYMJFqpMqpendZH9Srgq1w.text: The server at Tampopo just asked me if everything was ok   No. It isn't.  It is so much better than ok. My 4yo is destroying her bowl of ayako dan. My wife and I just demolished our tankatsu (mine with the delicious fried chicken topping). Everything was way better than "ok."  This is by far our favorite ramen spot. Everything is friendly, and there food is definitely a step up. They have some nice options beyond ramen. The servers are always friendly and efficient.  So, Tampopo employees ... please realize that you are far better than just "ok."

Rr03QoIjSNBTyzJawHEmyg.text: So I hear about this place for a while now, I finally got the chance to come and try it. It's a very smal place, we had a part of 9 and it was very cramped. We tried basically the whole menu, it was just ok. Nothing great about the broth, the noodles were ok. The braised pork was horrible, extra fatty, extra thick, and I couldn't even cut the meat it was so chewy. The charsiu was not bad, probably the best meat we tasted. The extra spicy broth should be labeled medium spicy. The spicy broth should be labeled normal. The curry was very flavorful but the noodles were so sticky, it was hard to eat. The pork bao for $4 was a waste. The bao itself tasted like it had been frozen and heated up. It was pretty gross for $4 each especially. The takoyaki was good, even though we didn't see it on the menu, we just asked for it. Overall it was ok, probably won't be going back anytime soon.

The noodles had the right amount of chewiness. I was hoping for the five spice egg, but it tasted like a normal boiled egg. JJf0maLOT7ntoKvJpOrlGg.text: I'm a sucker for Asian food and I always try to find new restaurants wherever I go. My boyfriend and I recently went to Tampopo Japanese Ramen and OMG!!!...it was just so good! Super authentic, honestly is the closest Japanese restaurant that I've visited that is somewhat closer to the real deal. Just like in Japan.!!!  . . . We tried the Hirata Buns (Steam Pork Buns) and they were soft and delicious. As well as the Seafood Ramen and the Tonkotsu Ramen. Just Perfect!!!

oz0HUIPCjziircmnD0lS9Q.text: I have had a cold all week and really needed ramen, never had Phoenix ramen but I know I needed it.  This was a lit lil' restaurant with cozy little seating.   Tabasaki - 3/5 The presentation was off-putting and I didn't try one at first but they had this soy sauce spice on that paired nicely with the crispy wing.  Spicy Miso ($10) large portion and it is definitely spicy, but something I'm able to handle with some water. I think it had too much bean sprout with mixed with the noodles so I didn't really like that but I wasn't being too choosy because it was really my first meal of the day. The pork belly was SOOOO flavorful. 10/10 for the chunks in the ramen and broth!

xwMqK97PnjeI86EqwU2ZQA.text: My friend obsessed with Japanese food forced us to have lunch here. All tried different noodle bowls and i would say curry ramen was the best one. Other ones would be good but not made for my taste buds. Fried dumplings  were awesome. Chicken wings had different taste as per Japanese cuisine and also we tried their local alcoholic drinks (3 flavors) which was quite strong and fruity flavored.   These guys have one of the only 10 noodles machine in US. So their noodles are in-house freshly made but I am not talented enough in noodles area to feel that difference

zfQvxDZA_Bb_MRaKZ_hKfw.text: A truly incredible 'hole in the wall' place! This place is incredible for the ramen lover or the ramen virgin! We started with the stuffed octopus balls and dumplings! The dumplings were slightly dry, but just the right amount of stuffing inside. The octopus balls were surprisingly incredible. My only drawback would be to have the sauce on the side, instead of drizzled all over.   Now, the ramen itself was very savory. I went with the concentrated version of the miso ramen. I went more traditional and was pleasantly surprised with the broth itself. I added the shrimp in, which I just wish I had added a little more meat.   While I didn't order the spicy ramen myself, I did try it and was delighted by the flavors. It had a slight kick, but with the noodles, simply perfect!   There were a few drawbacks to be expected. The egg broke up way too quickly. The atmosphere was busy and fun and the seating was pretty limited, but it certainly did add to the overall atmosphere. Overall though, a wonderful meal to enjoy and have great conversations over.

nx1SuTIajEHCnUDbPH3n4Q.text: This place's one location is listed next to job location in my list for considerations in a home to live in. It seems to emulates what I imagine the casual atmosphere of a ramen spot in Japan would be like as a bonus to their great, consistent ramen noodle soup with killer add-ins.

6l90Lpu02D__aiA_bIQ2oQ.text: Such good ramen! I got the rich broth with my ramen and it was the best decision. At first I didn't think it would be enough food, but it was the perfect amount for me.
